items.title: Node.js 18, WebAssembly 2.0, and Ember 4.3
items.content:
ğŸ‡ºğŸ‡¦ #â€‹586 â€” April 22, 2022

UnsubscribeÂ Â |Â Â Read on the Web

Lots of bits and pieces this week like running JavaScript on MS-DOS(!?), a deep dive on a V8 optimization, writing React apps on top of Ruby on Rails, a JS runtime for a tiny microcontroller, and, oh, a huge Node release..

JavaScript Weekly

Lexical: An Extensible Text Editor Library (That Does Things Differently) â€” Fresh from Meta (or Facebook, as my brain still calls it) comes a new text editor framework with accessibility, performance, and reliability at its heart. 22KB gzipped, supports React 18 (but can be used in a vanilla fashion), and a (native) iOS version is to follow. Remind you of Draft.js? Think of this as the next generation: Meta is â€“ theyâ€™re replacing Draft with Lexical in theirÂ apps.

Meta / Facebook

Node.js 18 (Current) Released â€” We get V8 10.1, Undici-powered global Fetch API support, Web Streams API support, Blob and BroadcastChannel APIs, the new test runner module, and the ability to create your own Node.js binaries with custom V8 startup snapshots. Node 18 goes LTS from October, but gets all the latest features untilÂ then.

The Node.js Team

Open-Source Backend Server for Web, Mobile & Flutter Devs â€” Appwrite is a secure, self-hosted solution that provides developers with a set of easy-to-use REST APIs to manage their core backend needs. You can build anything with Appwrite! Click here to learnÂ more.

Appwrite sponsor

The OpenJS Foundation's JavaScriptLandia Awards â€” Back in 2020, the OpenJS Foundation launched JavaScriptLandia as a sort of way to express support for the JS ecosystem, but hereâ€™s a practical result of it: you can nominate anyone in the JS ecosystem for an award for the hard work they do. So, um, yeah, find your favorite new library and nominate its creator, perhaps?

OpenJS Foundation

Ember 4.3 Released â€” One of JavaScriptâ€™s longest standing web application frameworks takes another step forward. Why use Ember? Well thereâ€™s a site explaining that too.

Anne-Greeth Schot-van Herwijnen and Jen Weber

IN BRIEF:

  • ğŸ‘¾ Got some spare time this weekend to build a game in JavaScript? The Gamedev.js Jam 2022 is on and finishes next Tuesday.

  • You can now make your GitHub profile private, if you wish.

  • We're big fans of Carbon for formatting source code for tweets, images, etc. but Chalkist is another option to consider now.

  • Did you know there's even JavaScript for MS-DOS now?

  • WebAssembly 2.0 is now a W3C First Public Working Draft.

  • Netlify has unveiled Edge Functions, a new serverless runtime powered byÂ Deno.

RELEASES:

Nuxt 3.0.0 RC1 â€“ Lots to see here for Vue 3 users.
Deno 1.21
React Redux 8.0 â€“ React bindings for Redux.
Neutralinojs 4.5.0 â€“ Lightweight x-platform desktop app framework.
fast-json-stringify 3.1.0 â€“ Even faster JSON.stringify()
Mineflayer 4.3 â€“ Minecraft bot dev framework.
Electron 18.1

ğŸ’» Jobs

Fullstack Developer â€” Konrad is hiring Fullstack developers to join our team in building products for the worldâ€™s most excitingÂ companies.
Konrad Group

Senior Software Engineer at This Dot Labs (Remote, Worldwide) â€” Great benefits working in modern tech stacks and amazing clients such as Google, Meta, Twilio, Cloudinary, Roblox, andÂ more.
This Dot Labs

Senior Software Engineers at Turo (SF | Remote/Hybrid Options) â€” The world's largest car sharing marketplace on a mission to put the worldâ€™s 1.5B cars to better use. We're hiring BE, FE, ML, iOS, Android & DevOps roles at allÂ levels.
Turo

ğŸ—“Â Register for Our May 5th State of Software Engineers Event â€” Join our panel discussion with experts from Hired, Amazon, Educative, and Signify Health as we discuss Hiredâ€™s 2022 State of Software EngineersÂ Report.
Hired

ğŸ“’Â Articles & Tutorials

â–¶Â Â Ember's Road to TypeScript and More â€” A dapper looking Chris Krycho (who has equally smart looking slides) promises his talk is good even for non-Ember and non-TypeScript using developers as the work theyâ€™ve been doing affects usÂ all.

Chris Krycho

Seven Web Component Tricks â€” A few things that may not be â€˜super obviousâ€™ about working with Web Components. Presented in a straightforward manner with codeÂ examples.

Dave Rupert

Transform Your File Uploads with Filestack â€” Give users access to file upload sources like Instagram, Dropbox, & Google Drive with just two lines of code - our advanced APIs can then help with conversions, transformations, intelligence andÂ more.

Filestack sponsor

V8's Faster Initialization of Instances with New Class Features â€” A technical deep dive into some work on optimizing the performance of initializing class fields and private methods â€“ work which now benefits all users of Node.js 18Â onward.

Joyee Cheung (V8)

â–¶Â Â What Key Was Pressed? (You Won't Believe How Keyboard Events Work) â€” A half-hour video diving into the intricacies of keyboard events and the best ways to go about handling userÂ input.

Jake Archibald & Ada Rose Cannon

A Quick Guide to Mitosis: Why You Need It and How You Can Use It â€” Forget cell division.. this Mitosis gives you code division, essentially letting you write components once and then letting you use them in React, Vue, Solid, Angular, andÂ elsewhere.

Alex Patterson

Integrate eSignatures in Your App in Less Than a Week

HelloSign, a Dropbox Company sponsor

Reducing Spam From mailto Links â€” Not necessarily the best way, but an interestingÂ approach.

Jack Childs

â–¶Â Â Are You Following This Vue Best Practice? â€” And itâ€™s only twoÂ minutes.
LearnVue

Terminal Wordle: Write a Wordle Clone for the Terminal with React Ink
John Ruble

How to Create a Modern CRUD App with Ruby on Rails and React
James Hibbard

Four Reasons to Avoid using npm link (and an alternative)
Hiroki Osame

ğŸ› Â Code & Tools

Leaflet 1.8.0: Mobile-Friendly Interactive Map Library â€” A huge release for the long standing and hugely popular library. The homepage has a liveÂ demo.

Leaflet

Kaluma 1.0: A Tiny JS Runtime for the RP2040 (Raspberry Pi Pico) â€” The RP2040 is a tiny microcontroller built by the Raspberry Pi folks, so for JavaScript to work, it needs to be tiny too. Enter Kaluma which can run on devices with just 64KB ofÂ RAM.

Kaluma Project

SpaceTime: A Lightweight Timezone Library â€” Use this to calculate times in other timezones. Has a Moment-like API but is immutable. No dependencies. GitHubÂ repo.

Spencer Kelly

Speed Up Your Builds with Buildkiteâ€™s New Plan â€” Set up CI/CD pipelines, frontend builds, ML training, Ops automation, security scanning, or IOT testingÂ ğŸ“¦

Buildkite sponsor

PicMo: A Plain JavaScript Emoji Picker â€” Gives you the option to use platform-native emojis or cross-platform ones via Twemoji, and you can even add your own custom emojis. Try some demosÂ here.

picmo

The Most Popular Node.js Frameworks in 2022 â€” A listicle, but not a bad one at all, and summarizes 11 different frameworks of various types.

Alex Ivanovs

HyperFormula 2.0.0: Spreadsheet-Like Calculation Engine â€” HyperFormula (GitHub repo) is a powerful Excel-inspired spreadsheet system (not just a control). Note that itâ€™s open source but dualÂ licensed.

HANDSONCODE sp. z o. o.

ğŸ¤ Â Other Cool Stuff

Mess with DNS: A Playground to Learn About DNS Concepts â€” Not JavaScript specific, but DNS management is one of those skills I think itâ€™s great for everyone to pickÂ up.

Julia Evans

Look Scanned: Make PDFs 'Look Scanned' â€” Sometimes there are organizations that need you to sign documents but arenâ€™t happy with you doing it on PDFs digitally and want something that looks real and 'scanned in.' This purely front-end based, WebAssembly powered tool tries to fake that effect for you, and itâ€™s open source too.

seedgou

items.title: On function composition in JavaScript
items.content:
ğŸ‡ºğŸ‡¦ #â€‹585 â€” April 15, 2022

UnsubscribeÂ Â |Â Â Read on the Web

JavaScript Weekly

JS Function Composition: Whatâ€™s The Big Deal? â€” Jamesâ€™ articles on JavaScript fundamentals have been very popular over the years, so itâ€™s great to see a new one focusing on a common activity: function composition â€” â€œWhy, then, do functional programmers get all worked up about it? Whatâ€™s the bigÂ deal?â€

James Sinclair

â€œChange Array by Copyâ€: Four New Non-Destructive Array Methods â€” Dr. Axel takes a look at another in-progress ECMAScript proposal (this one is in stage 3) that will introduce some non-destructive ways to reverse, sort, splice, and set (sort of) arrayÂ elements.

Dr. Axel Rauschmayer

Want to Dive Deeper into Stories of the Software Industry? â€” The Stack Overflow Podcast hosts conversations with fascinating guests about how technology is made and where itâ€™s headed. Itâ€™s the best place to learn about whatâ€™s happening in the world of software developmentÂ today.

Stack Overflow sponsor

TypeScript 4.7 Beta Released â€” ES module support for Node.js is now an official feature, and you can specify in package.json whether JS files are interpreted as ES modules or CommonJS modules. .mjs and .cjs extensions are also supported if you prefer. Thereâ€™s also improved function inference, instantiation expressions, and you can use typeof on private fields. Final TS releases tend to follow on quickly from betas, so expect 4.7 finalÂ soon.

Daniel Rosenwasser (Microsoft)

A 'Search Engine' for JavaScript Operators â€” Quick: name as many operators as you can! Got to about ten or so? This site covers about fifty with a quick explanation ofÂ each.

Josh W Comeau

IN BRIEF:

  • ğŸ¤ 20minJS is a new podcast from OpenReplay and it's already got several great episodes covering things like â–¶ï¸ Svelte, â–¶ï¸ SvelteKit, React state management, and â–¶ï¸ the Jamstack.

  • JSConf is taking place in Budapest this June â€” the speaker line-up is looking rather good.

  • Did you know if you make your GitHub repo private, even if briefly, you lose all your stars?

  • Some more news on npm packages being used to protest against Russia's ongoing invasion of Ukraine.

RELEASES:

Shepherd 9.1 â€“ Create guided tours for your app.
Jasmine 4.1 â€“ JS testing framework.
PouchDB 7.3 â€“ CouchDB-inspired syncing DB.
Oclif 3.0 â€“ Node.js CLI app framework.
Opal 1.5 â€“ Ruby to JavaScript transpiler.
react-hooks-testing-library 8.0
Create React App 5.0.1 â€“ Improves React 18 compatibility.

ğŸ’» Jobs

Director of Engineering @ ButterCMS (Remote) â€” Working closely with our founder and CEO, youâ€™ll own all technology, deliver on our roadmap, and most importantly, ensure that our customers areÂ successful.
ButterCMS

Senior Software Engineer at This Dot Labs (Remote, Worldwide) â€” Great benefits working in modern tech stacks and amazing clients such as Google, Meta, Twilio, Cloudinary, Roblox, andÂ more.
This Dot Labs

Ashby (YCW19) Is Hiring Remote Engineers to Change How Companies Hire â€” Join a kind, thoughtful team building powerful, quality software. <2h meetings/wk. Ship >8x per day. CI/CD takes <10minÂ ğŸš€
Ashby

Find JavaScript Jobs with Hired â€” Create a profile on Hired to connect with hiring managers at growing startups and Fortune 500 companies. It's free forÂ job-seekers.
Hired

ğŸ“’Â Articles & Tutorials

Fetch vs Axios: A Comparison for Fetching HTTP Resources â€” A beginner-level comparison of the long standing but borderline legacy Axios client versus using the FetchÂ API.

Meticulous

Building an Interactive Sparkline Graph with D3 â€” Being able to build out data visualizations is a handy skill for anyone â€“ this is a simple, elegant one.

Michelle Barker

A Rust Course Especially for JavaScript Developers â€” Includes side by side comparisons and builds on your familiarity with JavaScript to teach youÂ Rust.

Rust for JavaScript Developers sponsor

How to Build a CMS-Powered Blog with Nuxt â€” Create a blog without a server by using a headless CMS â€“ namely ButterCMS, in this case â€“ and the Nuxt Vue.jsÂ framework.

Uma Victor

A Guide to Optimizing JavaScript for Quick Page Loads â€” Touches on a few modern approaches including Astro, Qwik, andÂ Partytown.

Steve Sewell

How to Detect 'Long Press' Gestures in React Apps
Colby Fayock

Incremental Static Regeneration for Angular
Enea Jahollari

ğŸ› Â Code & Tools

Wild Wild Path: Object Property Paths with Wildcards and Regexps â€” A wild way to access properties in objects (which can be deeply nested) by way of string based queries that support wildcards and regular expressions. You need to see some examples to really getÂ theÂ idea.

ehmicky

YouTube.js 1.4: A Wrapper Around YouTube's Private API â€” The way this is described, I suspect your mileage could vary.. but itâ€™s an interesting idea and uses the same API as YouTubeÂ clients.

LuanRT

jc: CLI Tool That Converts Output of Popular CLI Tools toÂ JSON â€” This is written in Python but may be of use to you as a JavaScript developer as it converts either files or the output of over 50 other tools (including dig, du, iostat, and lsof) into easily processableÂ JSON.

Kelly Brazil

Integrate eSignatures in Your App in Less Than a Week

HelloSign, a Dropbox Company sponsor

React Admin 4.0: An Admin Panel for B2B Applications â€” A framework for building browser-based â€˜adminâ€™ apps on the backend of your choice (REST, GraphQL, etc. or you can write your own adapter). Thereâ€™s a demo if you want to see it live. MIT licensed, but does have a professional version too if support is required. GitHubÂ repo.

Marmelab

nextjs-blog-theme: A Customizable Blog Starter Built with Next.js and Tailwind â€” Includes dark and light themes and support for MDX. Try a live demo here (dark mode switch at the bottom of theÂ page).

netlify

scroll-snap: A Customizable 'Scroll Snap' Implementation â€” Bit of an older project thatâ€™s still maintained. Uses requestAnimationFrame() for 60fps scrolling performance and doesnâ€™t have any dependencies. Try itÂ here.

Luca Falasco

Gladys Assistant: A Privacy-First, Open-Source HomeÂ Assistant â€” It runs on any Linux machine (including a Raspberry Pi) and uses Node under theÂ hood.

Pierre-Gilles Leymarie

Mailgun.js: A JavaScript SDK for Mailgun â€” As in the email serviceÂ provider.
Mailgun Team

ğŸ•°Â Â ICYMI (Some older stuff that may catch your eye...)

  • A relatively new "unobtrusive" JS framework called Unpoly has emerged as a contender to Basecampâ€™s HTML over-the-wire mechanism, Hotwire.
  • Here's a straightforward tool from Nick Carneiro for converting curl commands into code â€”Â there's over a dozen output options, including JavaScript of course.
  • Raymond Camden looks at how to go about rendering a sortable, paginated table in JavaScript.
  • This Chrome 'knowledge' extension shows handy programming tips and snippets on your new tab page.
  • This blog post aims to round out your understanding of execution context in JavaScript â€”Â defining global, function, and eval execution contexts along with some examples too.

ğŸ˜†Â Â Well I found it useful..

Draw 'Handdrawn' Diagrams in VS Code with Excalidraw â€” Excalidraw is a popular online drawing tool for creating â€˜hand drawnâ€™ diagrams, and one of its coolest features is being able to export in SVG for lossless use in your pages. This VS Code extension brings it.. well, into VS Code, and is now blessed as being the official VS Code ExcalidrawÂ extension.

Visual Studio Marketplace / Achille Lacoin

Enea Jahollari 
  


ğŸ› Â Code & Tools





  
  
Wild Wild Path: Object Property Paths with Wildcards and Regexps â€” A wild way to access properties in objects (which can be deeply nested) by way of string based queries that support wildcards and regular expressions. You need to see some examples to really getÂ theÂ idea.
ehmicky 


  
  
YouTube.js 1.4: A Wrapper Around YouTube's Private API â€” The way this is described, I suspect your mileage could vary.. but itâ€™s an interesting idea and uses the same API as YouTubeÂ clients.
LuanRT 


  
  
jc: CLI Tool That Converts Output of Popular CLI Tools toÂ JSON â€” This is written in Python but may be of use to you as a JavaScript developer as it converts either files or the output of over 50 other tools (including dig, du, iostat, and lsof) into easily processableÂ JSON.
Kelly Brazil 


  
  
Integrate eSignatures in Your App in Less Than a Week
HelloSign, a Dropbox Company sponsor


  
  
React Admin 4.0: An Admin Panel for B2B Applications â€” A framework for building browser-based â€˜adminâ€™ apps on the backend of your choice (REST, GraphQL, etc. or you can write your own adapter). Thereâ€™s a demo if you want to see it live. MIT licensed, but does have a professional version too if support is required. GitHubÂ repo.
Marmelab 


  
  
nextjs-blog-theme: A Customizable Blog Starter Built with Next.js and Tailwind â€” Includes dark and light themes and support for MDX. Try a live demo here (dark mode switch at the bottom of theÂ page).
netlify 


  
  
scroll-snap: A Customizable 'Scroll Snap' Implementation â€” Bit of an older project thatâ€™s still maintained. Uses requestAnimationFrame() for 60fps scrolling performance and doesnâ€™t have any dependencies. Try itÂ here.
Luca Falasco 


  
  
Gladys Assistant: A Privacy-First, Open-Source HomeÂ Assistant â€” It runs on any Linux machine (including a Raspberry Pi) and uses Node under theÂ hood.
Pierre-Gilles Leymarie 


  
Mailgun.js: A JavaScript SDK for Mailgun â€” As in the email serviceÂ provider.
  
Mailgun Team 
  





        
ğŸ•°Â Â ICYMI (Some older stuff that may catch your eye...)
A relatively new "unobtrusive" JS framework called Unpoly has emerged as a contender to Basecampâ€™s HTML over-the-wire mechanism, Hotwire.
Here's a straightforward tool from Nick Carneiro for converting curl commands into code â€”Â there's over a dozen output options, including JavaScript of course.
Raymond Camden looks at how to go about rendering a sortable, paginated table in JavaScript.
This Chrome 'knowledge' extension shows handy programming tips and snippets on your new tab page.
This blog post aims to round out your understanding of execution context in JavaScript â€”Â defining global, function, and eval execution contexts along with some examples too.





        
ğŸ˜†Â Â Well I found it useful.. 


  





  
  
Draw 'Handdrawn' Diagrams in VS Code with Excalidraw â€” Excalidraw is a popular online drawing tool for creating â€˜hand drawnâ€™ diagrams, and one of its coolest features is being able to export in SVG for lossless use in your pages. This VS Code extension brings it.. well, into VS Code, and is now blessed as being the official VS Code ExcalidrawÂ extension.
Visual Studio Marketplace / Achille Lacoin

items.title: Format JavaScript as the Romans do?
items.content:
#â€‹584 â€” April 8, 2022

UnsubscribeÂ Â |Â Â Read on the Web

JavaScript Weekly

Veni, vidi, formatae!Â Announcing Rome Formatter: Super Fast JavaScript Formatting â€” Rome is an ambitious project that sets out to replace a lot of JS tools in one hit. But Rome wasnâ€™t built in a day, so theyâ€™re unveiling their take on Prettier-esque code formatting first. You can use it from the CLI but theyâ€™re recommending this VS Code extension primarily as a way to get a taste.

Rome Team

Writing Redux Reducers in Rust â€” We often cover how Rust is worming its way into numerous JavaScript areas (e.g. Rome, above!) but this is an interesting one: using Rust to write complex functions that are compiled down to WASM and used in a React/ReduxÂ app.

Arend van Beelen

Wallaby.js: 15x Faster JavaScript/jest Testing and Debugging â€” Wallaby runs your tests immediately as you type, with runtime values, errors and code coverage displayed in real-time right next to your code. Features have been designed specifically for testing, including new smart start which only runs test files you are currently workingÂ on.

Wallaby.js sponsor

JavaScript & Node Testing Best Practices: 2022 Edition â€” Fifty best practices divided into categories (testing, backend, frontend, etc.) complete with simple examples. We first linked to this 2Â½ years ago, but a new edition is now out, updated for 2022 standards and with translations in seven other languages including Chinese, Spanish andÂ French.

Yoni Goldberg

Announcing RedwoodJS 1.0 and $1M Funding â€” Tom, formerly a co-founder of GitHub, announces the 1.0 release of RedwoodJS, a full-stack framework perhaps originally best associated with the Jamstack but is essentially a React and GraphQL-powered framework for building whatever apps youâ€™dÂ like.

Tom Preston-Werner

ğŸ‡ºğŸ‡¦ Devs For Ukraine: An Online Event to Support Ukraine â€” Well known names including Addy Osmani, Cassidy Williams, Dan Abramov, and Sandi Metz are coming together on AprilÂ 25-26 with some great (online) talks to help raise funds for Ukraine-related causes.

Remote

IN BRIEF:

  • The British government has removed jQuery as a dependency from its gov.uk frontend apps â€“ Matt Hobbs shows off how this improves performance significantly.

  • If you use AWS Lambda for running serverless functions, you can now get direct HTTPS URLs for triggering functions, rather than having to use API Gateway. Serverless Framework already supports themÂ too. (â†’ via Serverless Status)

  • Node 12.22.12 (LTS) is out and it's the last Node 12 ever ğŸ‘‹ Node 17.9.0 (Current) is also out, but is a minor release.

  • Almost a third of the top 35 npm packages remain at risk due to a lack of 2FA use by associated accounts.

  • A developer makes the argument that JavaScript is safer for programming with integers than modern C â€“ it's no April Fool.

RELEASES:

Astro 1.0 Beta
React Native 0.68
Mapbox GL JS 2.8 â€“ Fast maps in the browser.
Swiper 8.1 â€“ Powerful mobile touch slider.
Danfo 1.1 â€“ Pandas-inspired data processing lib.
Cucumber.js 8.0 â€“ BDD for JavaScript.
pkg 5.6.0 â€“ Package Node apps into executables.

ğŸ’» Jobs

Fullstack Developer â€” Konrad is hiring Fullstack developers to join our team in building products for the worldâ€™s most excitingÂ companies.
Konrad Group

Senior JavaScript Developer (Warsaw or Remote) â€” Open Source rich text editor used by millions of users around the world. Strong focus on code quality. Join the CKEditorÂ team.
CKEditor

JavaScript Developer at X-Team (Remote) â€” Join the most energizing community for developers and work on long-term projects for Riot Games, FOX, Sony, Coinbase, andÂ more.
X-Team

Find JavaScript Jobs with Hired â€” Create a profile on Hired to connect with hiring managers at growing startups and Fortune 500 companies. It's free forÂ job-seekers.
Hired

ğŸ“’Â Articles & Tutorials

ShadowRealms: An ECMAScript Proposal for a Better eval() â€” Sat at stage 3, the fantastically named ShadowRealm API proposal lays out a new way to execute arbitrary JS code within a separate context to the currentÂ one.

Dr. Axel Rauschmayer

The Problems with JavaScript Begin with JavaScript â€” We love JS because of its flexibility and ease of use, but we ignore its security vulnerabilities. Get the guide on how to start with JavaScriptÂ security.

Feroot sponsor

How TypeScript's Compiler Compiles â€” Short and sweet but the diagrams areÂ fab.

Huy Tran

The Ultimate Guide on Creating Customizable AngularÂ Components â€” Covers lots of areas including best practices, anti-patterns, global styles, mixins, CSS variable usage, andÂ more.

Kevin Kreuzer

How to Test Component Interactions with Storybook â€” A walk through a component testing workflow when you want to simulate and verify userÂ behavior.

Varun Vachhar

â–¶Â Â Postlight Podcast: For Technology Leaders Solving ToughÂ Problems

Postlight sponsor

How Are Windows Runtime GUIDs Represented in JavaScript? â€” It's a small thing, but it's not often Microsoft's code archaeologist (his blog is packed with Windows trivia) mentions JavaScript.

Raymond Chen (Microsoft)

A Built-in Test Runner is Coming to Node and Why You Should Care
Shehzad Akbar

Build Your Own Markdown Editor with React and Codemirror 6
0xsuk

ğŸ› Â Code & Tools

â­ï¸Â React Libraries to Use in 2022 â€” The React ecosystem is so extensive that we even have a separate newsletter for React stuff and when it comes to libraries, the problem is one of too much choice, not too little, so an opinionated list like this can come inÂ handy.

Robin Wieruch

AgnosticUI: A Component Library for Numerous Frameworks â€” A set of components currently supporting React, Vue 3, Svelte and Angular, but you can make them work from vanilla JavaScript too. SomeÂ examples.

Rob Levin

Preview.js: Preview UI Components Instantly in Your IDE â€” Namely, VS Code or JetBrain IDEs, out of the box. Compatible with components built for React andÂ Vue.

Zenc Labs Pty

Keep Up with the Latest in Startups, Tech, & Programming in Just 5 Min â€” TLDR is a daily newsletter with links and TLDRs of the most interesting stories in startups ğŸš€, tech ğŸ“±, and codingÂ ğŸ’»

TLDR Newsletter sponsor

JSZip 3.9: Create, Read and Edit .zip Archive Files â€” A simple and elegant API. The homepage is pretty cool as it has a live demo and a handy how-to. Or you can just go for the GitHubÂ repo.

Stuart Knightley

article-parser: Node Library to Extract Articles from Web Pages â€” Give this a URL and, fingers crossed, you can get some useful content back. Live demo. You may not be surprised to know Readability is used under the hood to make most of this work :-)

Dong Nguyen

Cornerstone.js: Libraries to Build Web-Based Medical Imaging Apps
Open Health Imaging Foundation

rc-collapse: A Collapsing Content/Accordion Component for React
react-component

ğŸ“¥Â Reader Submissions

  • Cory Brown is happy to stir up a little controversy when he explains why he avoids async/await â€“ it certainly provoked a lot of comments.

  • Antonio Villagra De La Cruz wanted to submit his entire blog but given one of today's featured items, we thought we'd pick Optimizing a JS library with WebAssembly - a failed attempt to link :-)

  • The folks over at Cypress (best known as a Web testing tool) launched a four-course curriculum on Real World Testing with Cypress â€“ all open source too.

  • Maksim Balabash collected together just some of the npm supply chain issues over the past year into one place.

  • Pete Matsy sent in Reliable Webhook, a GUI-based tool for debugging webhooks. It's billed as 'charityware' with donations encouraged to the Come Back Alive fund for Ukraine.

Antonio Villagra De La Cruz wanted to submit his entire blog but given one of today's featured items, we thought we'd pick Optimizing a JS library with WebAssembly - a failed attempt to link :-)
The folks over at Cypress (best known as a Web testing tool) launched a four-course curriculum on Real World Testing with Cypress â€“ all open source too.

items.title: Time to get decorating
items.content:
#â€‹583 â€” April 1, 2022

UnsubscribeÂ Â |Â Â Read on the Web

ğŸ¤ Fingers crossed, but unless we've been successfully pranked ourselves, this is an April Fools' prank free zone! Sorry if you like a bit of frivolity on April 1st, but completeness and accuracy come before entertainment here. Boring, I know, but we don't stand a chance against YouTube or video games ğŸ˜†
__
Peter Cooper, your (boring, though still quite foolish) editor.

JavaScript Weekly

Decorators for ES6 Classes Proposal (Mostly) Reaches Stage 3 atÂ TC39 â€” We first linked to this proposal three years ago but itâ€™s now conditionally made it to stage 3 (with some tweaks required) and people are very excited. Despite dating from 2019, Mike Greenâ€™s explanation of the idea remains a good accessible overview of the basic idea, if the proposal feels too technical.

Ecma TC39

React 18 Released â€” The plan was for v18 to be an easy upgrade even if there were many changes under the hood.. and despite the introduction of a new concurrent renderer, Suspense, new hooks, automatic batching, and more, theyâ€™ve done a great job keeping the ship steady. The React 18 upgrade guide covers some things you need to consider, and if youâ€™re a completist, the changelog digsÂ deep.

The React Team

Studio 3T Manages Your Data, While You Wrestle Your App into Shape â€” Studio 3T's full suite of MongoDB tools lets you query quicker, develop with data even faster and turn queries into code automatically. Try it free for 30 days - no credit cardÂ needed.

Studio 3T sponsor

Electron 18.0 Released â€” Not content to let let React get all the v18 glory, the popular Electron cross-platform 'build desktop apps with JS, CSS and HTML' framework also reaches v18 with upgrades to Chrome 100 (also out this week), V8 10.0, and NodeÂ 16.13.2.

Keeley Hammond and Sofia Nguy

â–¶Â Â The Story of Next.js â€” A good balance of detail and high level overview to tell the Next.js story. Despite being just 12 minutes long, it goes into a lot more background and history than youâ€™d expect, too. Fingers crossed for Gatsby and Remix next,Â perhaps?

Tyler McGinnis

IN BRIEF:

  • VisibleV8 is a patched version of the V8 JavaScript engine specifically for monitoring and logging running JavaScript as explained ğŸ“„ in this academicÂ paper.

  • ğŸ‘¾ Kyle Simpson, of You Don't Know JS Yet fame, has been keeping me updated on progress with his Dwordly game â€“ it's quite fun, and an interesting change to Wordle.

  • Mish Ushakov wants to remind us that Next.js and Gatsby are not 'static site generators' - a common confusion.

  • The British government's official public facing sites have eventually all dropped jQuery as a dependency. ğŸ˜¢

RELEASES:

Preact 10.7.0 â€“ Tiny, fast React alternative.
wavesurfer 6.1.0 â€“ Navigable audio visualization.
Vite 2.9.0 â€“ Next gen frontend tooling.
D3 7.4.0 â€“ The Data-Driven Document library.
React Testing Library 13 â€“ Adds React 18 support.
MIDIVal 0.0.16 â€“ MIDI messaging library now has MIDI clock support.
ioredis 5 â€“ High perf Node.js Redis client.

ğŸ’» Jobs

Senior Web Developer (Node/ReactJS) - Remote â€” Millions get inspired and plan adventures with our apps. To help us make komoot.com the place to go to plan outdoor adventures, weâ€™re looking for a one of a kind Web Developer to join ourÂ team.
Komoot

Senior Front-End Engineer (Remote) â€” Weâ€™re looking for an engineer to join the web team at Unsplash. Small team but big product. React + strict TypeScript with plenty of functionalÂ programming.
Unsplash

Find JavaScript Jobs with Hired â€” Create a profile on Hired to connect with hiring managers at growing startups and Fortune 500 companies. It's free forÂ job-seekers.
Hired

ğŸ“’Â Articles & Tutorials

Locale Aware Sorting in JavaScript â€” When building a localized app, the default sorting logic for strings might not do quite what you want.. localeCompare and Intl.Collator to theÂ rescue.

Elijah Manor

How to Use Props in React â€” We first linked to this three years ago but Robin has been updating his posts to modern standards, so it remains a fantastic resource now too and is packed with prop-orientedÂ examples.

Robin Wieruch

14 Linting Rules To Help You Write Asynchronous JS Code â€” Walks through a variety of rules shipped by default with ESLint â€“ an interesting way to learn some bestÂ practices.

Maxim Orlov

How Lyft's Mobile Team Does Mobile CI at Scale â€” How does Lyft do mobile CI/CD, and unblock their ~200 mobile app contributors? Lyft shares all theÂ details.

Buildkite sponsor

The What, When, Why and How of Next.jsâ€™ New Middleware Feature â€” A look at a new beta feature in Next.js 12.0: middleware.

Sam Poder (Smashing Magazine)

Conquering JavaScript Hydration â€” Hydration plays a big role in many JS-based site generators but can sometimes be a performance bottleneck. This article is conceptual but digs into some of the ways in which newer frameworks are rethinkingÂ things.

Ryan Carniato

How to Deal with Optional Things and undefined in TypeScript
Mattie Behrens

How to Write a Linter Using tree-sitter in An Hour
Siraben

Remix: The Yang to React's Yin?
Kent C. Dodds

ğŸ› Â Code & Tools

Visual Studio Code March 2022 Released â€” VS Code gets updated every month, but this feels like one of the bigger updates for JavaScript developers in particular. Native local history support is the headline feature but the JS debugger now lets you collect and visualize heap profiles to keep an eye on memory allocation. We also now get JS highlighting when within HTMLÂ files.

Microsoft

a11y-dialog: A Lightweight, Accessible Way to Create Dialogs â€” Itâ€™s possible to replace JS dialogs with the <dialog> element in many cases now, but thatâ€™s not always desired. This is a nice implementation â€“ demo.

Kitty Giraudel

Integrate eSignatures in Your App in Less Than a Week â€” Enable document signing from anywhere with HelloSign's eSignature functionality. Test the API forÂ free.

HelloSign, a Dropbox Company sponsor

PLV8 3.1: Bringing the V8 Engine to the PostgreSQL Database â€” Postgres is both a hugely popular and hugely extensible relational database, and being able to write procedures in JavaScript rather than PL/pgSQL could appeal to you. Documentation.

plv8 team

Hackathon Starter: A Boilerplate for Node Web Apps â€” For when you might want to start building a Node app quickly including key features like auth/OAuth, Bootstrap 5, account management, emailÂ forms..

Sahat Yalkabov

Encoding.js 2.0: Convert or Detect (.jp) Character Encodings â€” Specifically for encodings that support Japanese characters, including Shift_JIS, EUC-JP, andÂ UTF-8/16.

polygonplanet

Build Internal Tools in Minutes with Retool, Where Visual Programming Meets the Power of Real Code

Retool sponsor

ts-audio 0.7.0: Simple API for AudioContext and Playing Audio Playlists â€” Here's aÂ demo.

Evandro Leopoldino GonÃ§alves

Flatbush: Fast Static Spatial Index for 2D Points and Rects
Vladimir Agafonkin

ğŸ“¥Â Reader Submissions

In recent months, we've been receiving an increasing amount of submissions from readers (thanks!) and while we use many of them, we don't have enough time to review everything to the right level. Given the backlog, we want to try out a new section to share things from our inbox to you more quickly:

  • Golgi by Rob Tweed is an interesting take on a UI framework built around Web Components and with no build steps required.

  • Maxim Orlov has written about how to run concurrent tasks within a defined limit using purely JavaScript.

  • spotify-mini is a Node wrapper around Spotify's Web API.

  • neo.mjs (which has just hit version 4.0) is a performance-oriented framework built around workers and its team is continuing to implement cool lookingÂ stuff.

If you have something to submit, email jsw@peterc.org or just hit reply to any issue of this newsletter and we'll see it :-)

ğŸ“¥Â Reader Submissions




In recent months, we've been receiving an increasing amount of submissions from readers (thanks!) and while we use many of them, we don't have enough time to review everything to the right level. Given the backlog, we want to try out a new section to share things from our inbox to you more quickly:
Golgi by Rob Tweed is an interesting take on a UI framework built around Web Components and with no build steps required.
Maxim Orlov has written about how to run concurrent tasks within a defined limit using purely JavaScript.
spotify-mini is a Node wrapper around Spotify's Web API.
neo.mjs (which has just hit version 4.0) is a performance-oriented framework built around workers and its team is continuing to implement cool lookingÂ stuff.
If you have something to submit, email jsw@peterc.org or just hit reply to any issue of this newsletter and we'll see it :-)

title: JavaScript Weekly
description: A newsletter of JavaScript articles, news and cool projects
